text: You could consider Liquibase - it's java-based but migrations are defined in an XML DSL so no knowledge of java is required.
We haven't used it in anger but are currently evaluating it.
Since you asked for python, im gonna do shameless self advertising:
http://flyingelephantsoftware.de/projects/locust/index.html
its written in python, but uses raw sql (so no abstraction).
basically it just keeps track, which migrationscripts has been executed, but in many projects of mine, this is enough.
It's unfortunate most of the migration libs are coupled to frameworks.
I've ended up using enumerated .sql files because I didn't find anything useful when I started.
I've since found, but haven't used http://code.google.com/p/sqlalchemy-migrate/.
It is tied to SQLAlchemy, but at least it's abstracted from other libs.
I use sequel to do all my migrations, I use it for Java based and rails based so it is framework agnostic.
It has a great little DSL for migrations with up and down, and you can even do raw SQL if you like.
why not writing a custom migration tool with python db api ?
http://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0249/ or use something similar to schema sync?
http://schemasync.org/
South seems pretty functional.
Have you looked at all under the covers to see if what it does (some library perhaps) could be extracted and wrapped around?
It seems to be in Python, so it should work already.
Also, has anyone tried http://chronicdb.com
Liquibase.
:) Though it is Java based it can be executed on the command line as long as you have a JVM, and it is not coupled to any particular persistence framework.
You can use XML to describe your migrations in a DSL, but it also supports plain SQL files.
We're really happy so far and I have started using it on my private pet project too.
